name: Identity for Betweenness
statement: If b is between a and b, then a equals b.
philosophy: This axiom prevents degenerate cases in the definition of betweenness, ensuring logical consistency in segment ordering.

name: Betweenness Symmetry
statement: If b is between a and c, then it is also between c and a.
philosophy: Betweenness should be reversible in a linear ordering of points. This symmetry aligns with intuitive understanding of lines.

name: Pasch's Axiom
statement: If a line enters a triangle, it must exit it.
formal: ∀a ∀b ∀c ∀p ∀q (Bet(a, p, c) ∧ Bet(b, q, c) → ∃x (Bet(p, x, b) ∧ Bet(q, x, a)))
philosophy: Pasch's axiom encodes the continuity of intersection, ensuring the structure of lines passing through triangles behaves as expected.

name: Lower Dimension Axiom
formal: ∃a ∃b ∃c (¬Bet(a, b, c) ∧ ¬Bet(b, c, a) ∧ ¬Bet(c, a, b))
philosophy: This axiom prevents collapse into one dimension by ensuring a plane structure with distinct directions.

name: Euclidean Axiom (Parallel Postulate)
statement: Given a point and a line, there is one parallel through the point.
formal: ∀a ∀b ∃x ∃y (Bet(a, x, y) ∧ Cong(a, x, a, b) ∧ Cong(a, y, a, b))
philosophy: This axiom characterizes flat geometry. Its acceptance or denial defines Euclidean vs. non-Euclidean space.

name: Continuity Axiom (Segment-Circle)
statement: If one point lies inside a circle and another outside, then the segment between them intersects the circle.
formal: (Circle C ∧ Inside(C, p) ∧ Outside(C, q)) → ∃x (OnCircle(C, x) ∧ Between(p, x, q))
philosophy: Captures the continuous nature of geometry and prevents logical gaps when moving between configurations.
